start.title:
From Earth To Stars

Trigonometric Tools for Astronomers
start.description: In this quest, you will explore the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile. Guided by astronomer Dr. Isabella Vega, you'll discover how trigonometry is used to measure cosmic distances and position satellite dishes.

S2_D1_F3_C0.heading: Welcome to ALMA
S2_D1_F3_C0.body: The sky over the Atacama Desert in Chile is wide and clear, making it great for looking at stars. In the desert, the ALMA Observatory stands with its large, white satellite dishes facing the sky. These satellite dishes work to study signals from space, helping scientists discover the universe's secrets.

S3.S3_D1_F4_C1: Hi, Alex! Welcome to ALMA. How was your drive?
S3.S3_D2_F5_C2: It was amazing! The desert is stunning, and those satellite dishes are even bigger than I imagined!
S3.S3_D3_F6_C1: They're truly remarkable! I remember feeling the same awe when I first saw them. Now, let's explore how they help us unravel the mysteries of the universe. Are you ready?
S3.S3_D4_F7_C2: Absolutely! I've always loved space. In college, I studied star distances, but the math was tough to follow.
S3.S3_D5_F8_C1: That's completely normal. A lot of concepts in space science rely on relationships between angles and distances and that's why we need trigonometry!
S3.S3_D6_F9_C2: Why is trigonometry so important?
S3.S3_D7_F10_C1: Because it shows how angles and distances are connected. Sine, cosine, and tangent define relationships between a right triangle's legs and hypotenuse, no matter its size.
S3.S3_D8_F11_C2: So, these ratios are kind of like rules that are true for all right triangles?
S3.S3_D9_F12_C1: Exactly! Once we understand those rules, we can use them in all sorts of ways. They help us break down complex problems into simple ones that we can solve with just a few calculations.
S3.S3_D10_F13_C2: That makes sense! I can't wait to see how it all comes together.
S3.S3_D11_F14_C1: Let's go to the control room, and I'll show you how these relationships work before we dive into any real-world problems. It's much easier to see them in action than just talk about them!

S4_D0_F15_C9.title: Right Angle Triangle Explorer

about.heading: Right Triangle Trigonometry
about.body:
The key relationship is:

  • tan(θ) = oppositeadjacent

where:

  • θ is the angle we can adjust
  • opposite is the leg across from θ
  • adjacent is the leg next to θ

The interactive shows how changing θ affects leg lengths and the tangent ratio, with special angles (30°, 45°, 60°).

help.heading: How to Use the Interactive
help.body:
• Click preset buttons for common angles (30°, 45°, 60°)
  • Observe changes in tangent ratios

The interactive helps visualize how angle changes affect triangle properties and trigonometric relationships.

S4_D0_F15_C9.ariaLabel: An interactive showing a right triangle

translations.tanFormula: tan(θ) = Opposite SideAdjacent Side
translations.tanFormulaText: tan theta equals opposite side divided by adjacent side

S4.S4_D1_F15_C1: Here we are in the control room! Let's start with exploring right triangles, with a focus on the tangent ratio. We'll keep the hypotenuse fixed at 100 units.
S4.S4_D2_F16_C2: Why do we have the hypotenuse fixed?
S4.S4_D3_F17_C1: Then we can focus all our attention on how the other sides become bigger or smaller compared to each other, that is what the tangent ratio actually tells us!
S4.S4_D4_F18_C1: On this monitor, you can see how the ratio between the opposite side, o, to the adjacent side, a, changes, which is what we call the tangent of an angle.
S4.S4_D5_F19_C1: Place the angle at 45°!
S4.S4_D6_F20_C1: Here o and a are equal! They are the same, and the tangent is 1. But notice what happens as the angle changes, why don't you look at what happens at 60°?
S4.S4_D7_F21_C1:
What follows:
If tan(θ) < 1, then θ < 45° and o < a.
And
If tan(θ) > 1, then θ > 45° and...
o - fill in this blank - ___ a.
S4.S4_D8_F22_C2: Oh, I see! So tan(θ) is just comparing those two sides?
S4.S4_D9_F23_C1: Exactly! The tangent ratio tells us how o relates to a—whether it's smaller, equal, or larger depending on θ. These ratios help us measure everything from the height of buildings right up to the stars themselves.
S4.S4_D10_F24_C2: Wait, we can measure stars' distances with triangles?
S4.S4_D11_F25_C1: Yes, that is exactly what the telescopes are for! Let's go check them out up close.

S5_D0_F26_C9.title: Stellar Parallax

about.heading: Stellar Parallax
about.body:
The key relationship is:

d =
1
P

where:

  • d is the distance to the star in parsecs (1 parsec = 3.26 light-years)
  • P is the parallax angle in arcseconds, which is the tiny apparent shift in the star's position as Earth orbits the Sun
  • This equation shows that stars with smaller parallax angles are farther away, while stars with larger parallax angles are closer to Earth

The interactive shows how Earth's yearly orbit creates these tiny angular shifts that astronomers can measure to find star distances.

help.heading: How to Use the Interactive Visualization
help.body:
Press the “Start Motion” button to make Earth orbit the Sun. Watch the line of sight change as Earth moves.

Observe the Parallax:

  • Track the “line of sight” connecting Earth to the target star
  • Notice how the star's position shifts against the distant background stars

Parallax Angle (P):

  • The angle (P) is calculated in real-time. It's displayed below the model as Earth's position changes
  • The parallax angle corresponds to the apparent shift you observe

S5_D0_F26_C9.ariaLabel: An interactive animation showing how we measure star distances: the Sun (orange circle) is at center, Earth (blue dot) orbits around it, and a star (yellow dot) is positioned above. Earth moves between two positions 6 months apart, forming a triangle with the star. The dark background with white dots represents distant stars.

S5.S5_D1_F26_C1: This is Arturo. He makes sure all our telescopes keep working, he has to be out in the desert a lot…
S5.S5_D2_F27_C3: Hi! You're Alex, the new intern? I hear you're curious about measuring star distances.
S5.S5_D3_F28_C2: Definitely! I just learned it is something with triangles?
S5.S5_D4_F29_C3: Indeed, as Earth moves, nearby stars seem to move a bit compared to the furthest stars we can see. By measuring that movement, we can figure out their distances.
S5.S5_D5_F30_C2: That sounds amazing! But how do we measure that, it seems really complex?
S5.S5_D6_F31_C1: Well, try this—hold up your finger, close one eye, then switch to the other eye. See how your finger appears to move?
S5.S5_D7_F32_C2: Oh yeah! My finger looks like it's jumping, even though it's not moving.
S5.S5_D8_F33_C1: This is called parallax, and the same thing happens with stars. As Earth moves, we see nearby stars from slightly different positions in space. By measuring how far a star ‘jumps', we can determine its distance.
S5.S5_D9_F34_C3: The amount of movement tells us how far away something is, close stars show a lot of parallax, a lot of movement, far away stars not so much. You can try again with your finger.
S5.S5_D10_F35_C3: Here, look at my tablet. Try starting the animation—you'll see how Earth's motion creates a change in our perspective.
S5.S5_D11_F36_C3: The parallax angle is measured from these two positions, six months apart.
S5.S5_D12_F37_C1: Before we dive deeper, let me explain two important terms we use in astronomy: arcseconds and parsecs.
S5.S5_D13_F38_C1: An arcsecond is a very tiny unit we use to measure angles. You know degrees, right? Think of one degree like an hour on a clock. Inside that hour, there are 60 minutes—or in this case, 60 arcminutes.
S5.S5_D14_F39_C3: But Dr. Vega, for these stars we actually have to go even smaller… Each arcminute is further divided into 60 arcseconds.
S5.S5_D15_F40_C3: That means 1 degree has 3,600 arcseconds—we have to use this, the angles we measure here are so tiny that using degrees would be way too imprecise!
S5.S5_D16_F41_C2: So arcseconds tell us something about the angle, but what about the star's distance? I remember you mentioning something like a parsec.
S5.S5_D17_F42_C1: Instead of using miles or kilometers, astronomers use a unit called a parsec, which is directly tied to arcseconds.
S5.S5_D18_F43_C2: Wait, parsec? What is that?
S5.S5_D19_F44_C3: A parsec is a unit of distance. It comes from real astronomical measurements—just like we're using here.
S5.S5_D20_F45_C1: A star is exactly 1 parsec away if its parallax angle is 1 arcsecond. It's a direct way to connect angles with distances in space, just like the ratios from before.
S5.S5_D21_F46_C2: So, it's not just a sci-fi term—it's real science?
S5.S5_D22_F47_C1: Absolutely! Imagine a giant isosceles triangle in space. The star is at one vertex, and Earth's positions 6 months apart form the base, which has a length of 2 astronomical units (AU).
S5.S5_D23_F48_C1: Now, if we split that isosceles triangle right down the middle, we get two right triangles. The Sun lies at the midpoint of the base, making a right angle there.
S5.S5_D24_F49_C2: Oh, I see! The right angle is at the Sun in the model.
S5.S5_D24_F49_C1: Correct. And here’s the neat trick—if we observe a star and notice it shifts by just 1 arcsecond , that shift corresponds to a distance of 1 parsec . That’s how astronomers measure stellar distances!

S6_D0_F50_C9.title: Stellar Parallax
S6_D0_F50_C9.ariaLabel: The image shows stellar parallax measurement, depicting how a star's position appears to shift when viewed from Earth 6 months apart. The diagram shows a right triangle with the Sun at the base, Earth's positions 1 astronomical unit apart, and a star at 1 parsec distance, creating a parallax angle of 1 arcsecond.

translations.equations:
tan(P) =
1 AU
d
tan(P) ≈ P
P ≈
1
d
d =
1
P
translations.equations_1:
tan(P) =
1 AU
d
translations.equations_2:
tan(P) =
1 AU
d
tan(P) ≈ P
P ≈
1
d

S6.S6_D1_F50_C1: The relationship uses the tangent function. We call the angle in the right triangle at the point of the star the parallax angle!
S6.S6_D2_F51_C1: Since the parallax angle P is tiny, and the adjacent side (which we measure in parsecs) is really large, the tangent ratio becomes really small. And we are dividing 1 by a really large number, so tan(P) is very close to...
S6.S6_D3_F52_C1: And finally, solving for d.
S6.S6_D4_F53_C2: I see. The smaller the angle, the larger the distance.
S6.S6_D5_F54_C1: Exactly! Parallax, arcseconds, and parsecs all work together to help us figure out how far away stars are. By understanding how they connect, we can measure distances in space with amazing accuracy!
S6.S6_D6_F55_C3: That's all really nice Dr. Vega, but I am getting a bit cold. Can we go back inside the control room? Max just figured out the distance to a really cool black hole!
S6.S6_D7_F56_C1: Of course! Let's see some more uses.

S7_D0_F57_C9.title: Stellar Parallax Math
S7_D0_F57_C9.ariaLabel: An Interactive showing how blackhole distance is measured, with the Sun at the center and Earth shown in two opposite positions in its orbit. Red lines extend from both Earth positions to a distant blackhole, forming a tiny angle. The diagram includes a measurement slider and shows the calculated distance to the blackhole.

about.heading: Understanding Stellar Parallax Math
about.body:
Key Equation:

d =
1
P

where:

  • d is the distance to the black hole in parsecs
  • P is the parallax angle in arcseconds

What This Means

When we observe a celestial object from Earth at different times of year, it appears to move slightly against the background of more distant celestial objects. This apparent movement creates a tiny angle called the parallax angle (P).

The closer the object is to Earth:

  • The larger the parallax angle (P)
  • The smaller the distance (d)

The further the object is from Earth:

  • The smaller the parallax angle (P)
  • The larger the distance (d)

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
You're measuring how far away the black hole is by observing how much it appears to shift as Earth moves around the Sun.

Try this example:

  • Set the slider to 0.2 arcseconds
  • Observe the green arc—this is your parallax angle
  • Calculate the distance using the formula:
    d =
    1
    P
    d =
    1
    0.2

    d = 5 parsecs

  • Notice how reducing the parallax angle on the slider means the black hole is farther away from Earth!

S7.S7_D1_F57_C1: Six months ago, we detected a new black hole! It was an exciting discovery, but we didn't know how far away it was.
S7.S7_D2_F58_C2: A black hole? That's incredible! How do we figure out its distance?
S7.S7_D3_F59_C1: Great question! We measured its parallax angle yesterday. Now, we need your help to calculate its distance. Let's look at the monitor!
S7.S7_D4_F60_C1: Try adjusting the parallax angle in the interactive and see how the distance changes.
S7.S7_D5_F61_C2: So, is distance always related to the parallax angle in the same way?
S7.S7_D6_F62_C1:
Yes! Let's use the formula:
distance (in parsecs) = 1 / parallax angle (in arcseconds)
For this black hole, the parallax angle is 0.4 arcseconds. How far away, in parsecs, is the black hole?
S7.S7_D7_F63_C2: Using the formula, that means the black hole is about 2.5 parsecs away!
S7.S7_D8_F64_C1: That's right! The farther the object, the smaller the parallax angle. This helps us measure distances correctly and interpret our observations of faraway objects.

S8.S8_D1_F65_C2: That's really cool! But I am still confused. These telescopes look like big satellite dishes, and I see them being used on many things - on TV towers, ships, those old televisions. Do those also use parallax?
S8.S8_D2_F66_C1: Not really. Satellite dishes are crucial for sending and receiving signals. Their positioning needs to be extremely precise to ensure strong and reliable connections. But they do not use parallax.
S8.S8_D3_F67_C1: Parallax is used to measure far away stars. For satellites, they move way too quickly to use a tangent. Instead, we need multiple telescopes if we want to pinpoint the exact distance of a satellite to earth!

S9_D0_F68_C9.title: Telescope Triangulation
S9_D0_F68_C9.ariaLabel: Signal triangulation simulator with adjustable telescopes and source positions. Visualizes geometric relationships and mathematical calculations used in determining signal locations through triangulation methods.

about.heading: The Telescope Triangulation
about.body:
We use the Law of Sines to calculate distances from our telescopes to the signal source:

Sine A over A, equals sine B over b equals sine C over c
sin(A)
a
=
sin(B)
b
=
sin(C)
c

In our triangle:

  • (a) = distance to signal source from Telscope 2
  • (b) = distance to signal source from Telescope 1
  • (A) = angle at Telescope 1
  • (B) = angle at Telescope 2

Key Point:

By measuring the base distance and the angles at both telescopes, we can calculate the exact distances to the signal source.

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
You're using two telescopes to locate a signal source in the sky. The Law of Sines helps us determine its precise position!

Quick Tips:

  • Drag the signal source (satellite) anywhere in the sky
  • Watch how angles change as you move either antennas or source
  • Notice the relationship between angles and distances

Try This:

  • Move the signal source away from the telescope and observe how the angle at the source get smaller
  • Watch the numbers update in real-time

translations.dragInstructions: Drag source to see triangle calculations
translations.interactiveInstructions: This is a signal triangulation interactive. Use arrow keys to move the telescopes and source. Measurements update in real-time.
translations.sourceButtonInstructions: Use left/right arrow keys to adjust the source position.

S9.S9_D1_F68_C3: We do need two telescopes for this however. To create a little triangle, like here on the screen. Or actually a really big triangle in real life.
S9.S9_D2_F69_C2: That's really cool! But how do we use trigonometry to know how far away a satellite is? Aren't they moving all the time?
S9.S9_D3_F70_C1: Well some satellites do move really fast, yet others do not move at all, with respect to the Earth's surface. In both cases however, we can use the Law of Sines to calculate the altitude at which they fly.
S9.S9_D4_F71_C1:
The Law of Sines states that in any triangle, each side is proportional to the sine of the angle opposite that side. This relationship can be written as:
sine A over a equals sine B over b equals sine C over c
sin(A)
a
=
sin(B)
b
=
sin(C)
c

This formula helps us find unknown sides or angles in a triangle when enough information is given.
S9.S9_D5_F72_C2: When would we use this formula?
S9.S9_D6_F73_C1: We use it in specific cases. When we know two angles and one side. Let me show you a practical example.
S9.S9_D7_F74_C1:
Let's say we have the following setup:
  • Telescope 1 is angled at 45°
  • Telescope 2 is angled at 60°
  • The distance between them is 600 miles
S9.S9_D8_F75_C2: So we can use Law of Sines here?
S9.S9_D9_F76_C1: Exactly! Because we know two angles and the length of the side between the angles. With that, we first find the third angle using the rule that a triangle's angles sum to 180°.
S9.S9_D10_F77_C1: Angle measure at Satellite = 180° − 45° − 60° = 75°
S9.S9_D11_F78_C2: What if we didn't have both angles? Could we still solve this?
S9.S9_D12_F79_C1: Yes! If we had one angle and two sides, and we'd use the Law of Cosines. If we had two angles and a side not between them, and we'd still use the Law of Sines.
S9.S9_D13_F80_C2: So the Law of Sines works when we have two angles and a side known?
S9.S9_D14_F81_C1: Precisely! Now, let's apply it to our telescope problem. Using the Law of Sines, calculate the distance from each telescope to the satellite.
S9.S9_D15_F82_C2: I got it! The distance from Telescope 1 to the satellite is 440 miles, and from Telescope 2 to the satellite is 538 miles!
S9.S9_D16_F83_C1: Perfect! Now both telescopes are correctly aligned, and the signal is strong enough to reach the satellite. Without this calculation, we'd be guessing—and in space, there's no room for guesswork!
S9.S9_D17_F84_C2: That makes sense—math isn't just numbers; it's what lets us connect with things across space, even satellites!

S10.S10_D1_F85_C2: So, that's how trigonometry helps here at ALMA?
S10.S10_D2_F86_C1: Exactly! These principles are essential for exploring the universe. From measuring star distances using parallax to positioning telescopes with the Law of Sines.
S10.S10_D3_F87_C2: Wow, I never realized math could be so powerful!
S10.S10_D4_F88_C1: It's not just a school subject—it's a tool that helps us uncover the mysteries of space. Next time you look at the night sky, remember: trigonometry is helping us understand it better.
S10.S10_D5_F89_C2: So all those tiny angles and calculations really add up to big discoveries, huh?
S10.S10_D6_F90_C1: Exactly. Even the smallest change in angle can lead to new insights. Every calculation counts. Who knows what cosmic wonders we'll discover next?

S11.S11_D1_FX_C9:
From Earth to the Stars

Trigonometric Tools for Astronomers
S11.S11_D2_FX_C9:
You completed the From Earth to the Stars: Trigonometric Tools for Astronomers STEAMQuest!

  • You helped Alex and Dr. Vega explore how trigonometry and the right triangle are used in space research.
  • You explored how parallax measurements are used to determine the distances to faraway stars and galaxies.
  • You discovered how the Law of Sines is used to position antennas accurately.
  • You gained hands-on experience in applying trigonometry to real-world challenges like mapping galaxies and pinpointing signal origins.

Great work, young astronomer—your journey to the stars has just begun!

quest_completion.subheading: You Have Explored the Trigonometric Tools for Astronomers Models
quest_completion.content:
You completed the From Earth to the Stars: Trigonometric Tools for Astronomers quest!

  • •You helped Alex and Dr. Vega explore how trigonometry and the right triangle is used in space research
  • •You explored how parallax measurements are used to determine the distances to faraway stars and galaxies
  • •You discovered how the Law of Sines is used to position telescopes accurately
  • •You gained hands-on experience in applying trigonometry to real-world challenges like mapping galaxies and pinpointing signal origins

Great work, young astronomer—your journey to the stars has just begun!

parallax.definition: Parallax The apparent shift in the position of a celestial object, such as a star or black hole, when viewed from two different points in Earth’s orbit (six months apart). This effect occurs because the observer’s viewpoint changes.

parallax_angle.definition: Parallax Angle The actual angle formed at the star by drawing lines from the two observation points on Earth. This angle is the measurable quantity that astronomers use in trigonometry to calculate the object’s distance.

black_hole.definition: Black Hole is a place in space where gravity pulls so much that even light cannot get out.

black_holes.definition: Black Holes are places in space where gravity pulls so much that even light cannot get out.

parsec.definition: Parsec is a unit of length used to measure the large distances to astronomical objects outside the Solar System.

parsecs.definition: Parsecs are a unit of length used to measure the large distances to astronomical objects outside the Solar System.

arcsecond.definition: Arc-Second is a unit of angular measurement. One degree is divided into 60 arcminutes, and each arcminute is divided into 60 arcseconds. That makes 1 arcsecond equal to 1/3600th of a degree—small enough to measure the tiny parallax angles in astronomy.

arcseconds.definition: Arc-Seconds is a unit of angular measurement. One degree is divided into 60 arcminutes, and each arcminute is divided into 60 arcseconds. That makes 1 arcsecond equal to 1/3600th of a degree—small enough to measure the tiny parallax angles in astronomy.

au.definition: AU is used in measuring distances within the Solar System or around other stars. One AU is the average distance from Earth to the Sun.

sine.definition: Sine (sin(θ)) is the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse in a right-angled triangle.

cosine.definition: Cosine (cos(θ)) is the ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse in a right-angled triangle.

tangent.definition: Tangent (tan(θ)) is the ratio of the opposite side to the adjacent side in a right-angled triangle.

sines.definition: Sine (sin(θ)) is the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse in a right-angled triangle.

cosines.definition: Cosine (cos(θ)) is the ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse in a right-angled triangle.
